definition: **noun / tonearm part.** A detachable cartridge-mounting shell that plugs into an S-shaped tonearm with a bayonet or SME-type connector, allowing fast cartridge swaps. Introduced in the 1960s alongside modular turntable design philosophy, the plug-in headshell revolutionized cartridge experimentation by eliminating the need to rewire tonearm leads for each swap. The shell typically features four color-coded pin connectors (white, red, blue, green) that mate with corresponding headshell leads, plus mounting slots for standard half-inch cartridge spacing. Japanese manufacturers like Technics popularized the bayonet-twist design with their SL-1200 series, making DJ cartridge replacement a 30-second operation rather than a delicate rewiring session. Audiophile implementations favor the SME-style locking connector, which provides superior rigidity and electrical contact. Headshell mass (typically 5-15 grams) affects tonearm resonance calculations, with magnesium and carbon fiber shells prized for their stiffness-to-weight ratios. The system's convenience comes with minor sonic trade-offs—purists argue that hardwired tonearms eliminate connection-point signal degradation—but the flexibility to maintain separate cartridges for mono, 78s, and stereo playback makes plug-in headshells indispensable for serious collectors. Vintage headshells from Technics, Audio-Technica, and Ortofon command premium prices when original packaging survives.
etymology: Coined in the 1960s from "plug-in" (detachable electrical component) and "headshell" (the cartridge-mounting terminus of a tonearm), reflecting the modular hi-fi component philosophy of the era.
